0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Switch from a 21-day regimen of oral contraceptive by starting first dose after completion of active tablets. Switch from a 28-day regimen of oral contraceptive by starting first dose after completion of active tablets and skipping inactive tablets. Switch from another progestin-only pill at any time.
  • If breastfeeding, may switch to another method of birth control at any time; do not switch to the combination oral contraceptive until breastfeeding is stopped or until at least 6 months after delivery.
  • Contraception: 1 tablet ORALLY daily at the same time of day; administration is continuous between pill packs.
  • Contraception: Begin therapy on the first day of menstrual cycle; if dosing starts on a day other than the first day of menstrual cycle, a nonhormonal backup method of contraception is recommended for the first 48 hours of therapy.
  • Contraception: Therapy may be initiated 6 weeks postpartum in fully lactating (no formula) women or 3 weeks postpartum in partially lactating (some formula) women.
  • Contraception: Therapy may be initiated on the next day following an abortion or miscarriage.

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Use before menarche is not indicated.
  • Switch from a 21-day regimen of oral contraceptive by starting first dose after completion of active tablets. Switch from a 28-day regimen of oral contraceptive by starting first dose after completion of active tablets and skipping inactive tablets. Switch from another progestin-only pill at any time.
  • If breastfeeding, may switch to another method of birth control at any time; do not switch to the combination oral contraceptive until breastfeeding is stopped or until at least 6 months after delivery.
  • Contraception: After menarche: 1 tablet ORALLY daily at the same time of day; administration is continuous between pill packs.
  • Contraception: Begin therapy on the first day of menstrual cycle; if dosing starts on a day other than the first day of menstrual cycle, a nonhormonal backup method of contraception is recommended for the first 48 hours of therapy.
  • Contraception: Therapy may be initiated 6 weeks postpartum in fully lactating (no formula) women or 3 weeks postpartum in partially lactating (some formula) women.
  • Contraception: Therapy may be initiated on the next day following an abortion or miscarriage.

mono.title: Black Box Warning
mono.mono:
Oral (Tablet)
Cigarette smoking greatly increases the possibility of suffering heart attacks and strokes. Women who use oral contraceptives are strongly advised not to smoke.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Abnormal and undiagnosed genital bleeding
  • Acute liver disease
  • Benign or malignant liver tumors
  • Carcinoma of the breast
  • Hypersensitivity to any component of the product
  • Pregnancy

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Black Box Warning:
  • -- Increased risk of serious cardiovascular disease with cigarette use; women who use oral contraceptives are strongly advised not to smoke
  • Endocrine and Metabolic:
  • -- Changes in carbohydrate or lipid metabolism may occur, particularly in diabetic and prediabetic patients; monitoring recommended
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Benign hepatic adenomas and an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma have been reported with combined oral contraceptive use
  • Neurologic:
  • -- New onset or worsening of migraine or severe headaches with focal neurological symptoms have been reported; discontinue use and evaluate cause
  • Reproductive:
  • -- Increased risk of breast cancer has been reported with combined oral contraceptive use
  • -- Ectopic pregnancy may occur
  • -- Delayed follicular atresia and ovarian cysts have been reported; surgical intervention may be required
  • -- Irregular menstrual patterns may occur; rule out pregnancy if prolonged amenorrhea occurs
  • -- Does not protect against sexually transmitted diseases

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono: Fetal risk cannot be ruled out. (TH)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

mono.title: Adverse Effects
mono.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea
  • Neurologic:Headache
  • Reproductive:Abnormal menstrual cycle, Breast tenderness, Irregular periods
Serious
Reproductive:Ectopic pregnancy

mono.title: Mechanism Of Action
mono.mono: Norethindrone is a progestin contraceptive that prevents ovulation, inhibits sperm penetration by thickening the cervical mucus, reduces the midcycle luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone peaks, delays the movement of ovum through the fallopian tube, and alters the endometrium lining.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Rate of absorption, Oral: rapid
  • Tmax, Oral: 1 to 2 hours
  • Bioavailability, Oral: 65%

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• Protein binding: sex hormone-binding globulin, 36%; albumin, 61%
  • Vd: 4 L/kg

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Hepatic: extensive via reduction and conjugation
  • Sulfate conjugates (unknown): major circulation metabolites
  • Glucuronide conjugates (unknown): major urinary metabolites

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Renal: greater than 50% (primarily metabolites); less than 5% unchanged
  • Feces: 20% to 43% (primarily metabolites); less than 5% unchanged
  • Total body clearance: 600 L/day

mono.title: Administration
mono.mono:
Oral
  • Take exactly as directed and at the same time of day.
  • Administration is continuous between pill packs.
  • Missed doses: If dose is delayed by more than 3 hours, take the missed dose as soon as remembered; nonhormonal backup contraception is recommended for the next 48 hours of therapy.
  • Missed doses (including vomiting soon after dose): With 1 or more missed doses, take a missed dose as soon as remembered; nonhormonal backup contraception is recommended for the next 48 hours of therapy.

mono.title: Monitoring
mono.mono:
• prevention of unintended pregnancy is indicative of efficacy
  • glucose tolerance and insulin requirements in prediabetic and diabetic women
  • annual history and physical examination for all sexually active women using oral contraceptives

mono.title: How Supplied
mono.mono:
• Generic
    Oral Tablet: 0.35 MG
  • Camila

  • Deblitane

  • Errin

  • Heather

  • Jencycla

  • Lyza
    Oral Tablet: 0.35 MG
  • Nora-BE

  • Norlyroc

  • Nor-QD

  • Ortho Micronor

  • Sharobel
    Oral Tablet: 0.35 MG

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
PROGESTINS
OVERDOSE: Rarely do acute ingestions result in obvious clinical manifestations. CHRONIC: Most adverse effects are related to chronic or high-dose therapy. Headache, dizziness, irregular menses, mastalgia, bloating, depression, decreased libido, cholestatic jaundice, hepatitis, oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea and thromboembolism may occur with chronic therapy.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
PROGESTINS
  • Support: Single acute overdoses will seldom result in toxicity. Supportive treatment is adequate in most situations.
  • Decontamination: Gastric decontamination is probably only necessary after very large ingestions or with toxic coingestants; administer activated charcoal in these cases.
  • Monitoring of patient: CHRONIC TOXICITY: Discontinue medication and monitor for signs of toxicity and treat symptomatically. Obtain a baseline CBC and hepatic and renal function tests in symptomatic patients.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
PROGESTINS
Toxicity is unlikely following an acute overdose. There are insufficient data reported in the literature to assess the range of toxicity in terms of mg/kg ingested.

mono.title: Clinical Teaching
mono.mono:
• Advise patient to practice safe sex. Drug does not protect against sexually transmitted diseases.
  • Drug may cause nausea, dizziness, headache, breast tenderness, or irregular periods.
  • Tell patient to report persistent or recurrent abnormal vaginal bleeding, amenorrhea, or severe abdominal pain.
  • Advise patient to take drug every day, at the same time of day, with no more than 24 hours between doses, including during bleeding episodes.
  • Patient should not smoke during therapy, as this increases the risk of heart attack or stroke.
  • Review with patient the procedure for handling a missed dose.
